Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs and Co-PIs of grants supported through the NSF-NIH-ANR-BMBF-BSF Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) program meet annually. This tenth meeting of CRCNS investigators brings together a broad spectrum of computational neuroscience researchers supported by the program, and includes poster presentations, talks, plenary lectures, and workshops. The meeting is scheduled for October 16-18, 2014 and is hosted by Arizona State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided supplemental funds to support the Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) 2014 Principal Investigator meeting which was held in Tempe, Arizona on October 16 - 18, 2014. The meeting brought together principal investigators and other personnel from grants funded under the CRCNS program to present their research results in oral and poster presentations and to discuss research progress and the future directions of the field. The CRCNS program supports collaborative activities that advance the understanding of nervous system structure and function, mechanisms underlying nervous system disorders, and computational strategies used by the nervous system. 

The funds also supported a Workshop on Open Science and Resources for Computational Neuroscience on October 16, 2014 prior ro the main CRNCS Meeting. Computational neuroscience researchers spend billions of dollars and million of hours producing data and models, but there are challenges when building a computational or analytical edifice on top of others' research output. Emerging solutions to this challenge center around data standards, model description languages, reproducibility, model and data-sharing infrastructure, and transparent methods for evaluating the scope and validity of previous work. This workshop presented progress along numerous fronts and how it has begun to allow researchers to answer specific scientific questions more quickly, inexpensively, and reliably. 

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2015
Modified by: Sharon M Crook
